text.p: Let [mathjaxinline]T: \mathbb R^4 \rightarrow \mathbb R^4[/mathjaxinline] be a linear transformation with standard matrix [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline]. Suppose the second row of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] is equal to three times the last row of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] minus the first row of [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline]. Which of the following must be true? Click all that apply.

choice.text: The equation [mathjaxinline]Ax = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ 3 \\ 5 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline] has exactly one solution
[mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] row reduces to the identity matrix

font.p: Because one of the rows is a linear combination of the others, the rows are not linearly independent and the matrix is not invertible. If we row reduce this matrix, we will not get the identity matrix, but will instead have a row of all zeros and at least one free variable. Therefore none of the conditions of the Invertible Matrix Theorem are satisfied: [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is neither onto nor into, etc. Since [mathjaxinline]A[/mathjaxinline] has a free variable, no [mathjaxinline]Ax = v[/mathjaxinline] equation can have a unique solution (it might have zero solutions, or infinitely many).
